docs.abstract: South African prosecutor announces that he will not bring bribery charges against Solomon Kerzner, step that is likely to smooth way for gambling magnate to get license to operate casino in Atlantic City; Kerzner, chmn of Sun International Hotels, was accused of paying $600,000 bribe in 1986 to leader of South African puppet state, Transkei, to preserve his company's gambling monopoly in that country; Kerzner says he was victim of extortion; NJ Division of Gaming Enforcement says it will continue its own investigation into Kerzner's activities (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)
docs.lead_paragraph: A South African prosecutor announced yesterday that he would not bring bribery charges against Solomon Kerzner, a step that is likely to smooth the way for the gambling magnate to get a license to operate a casino in Atlantic City. Thomas N. Auriemma, deputy director of the New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement, said his agency would continue its own investigation into Mr. Kerzner's activities. But the decision by a South African attorney general, Christo Nel, certainly helps Mr. Kerzner's cause.

headline.main: Harrah's Chosen as Operator Of Casino on Missouri River

docs.lead_paragraph: Harrah's Casino Hotels said yesterday that it had been chosen to build a $50 million, 1,550-passenger riverboat casino in North Kansas City, Mo., for operation on the Missouri River beginning in the second quarter of 1994. The ship will have about 900 slot machines and 55 gaming tables. Harrah's is a subsidiary of the Memphis-based Promus Companies, with interests in hotels and gaming. Promus is currently building two casino riverboats for a complex in downtown Joliet, Ill. It will begin construction in March of a riverboat for Vicksburg, Miss. And it is in exclusive negotiations with the City of Shreveport, La., for a riverboat casino there.

headline.main: Hilton Plans to Seek Atlantic City License

byline.original: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it planned to apply for a license to operate a hotel and casino in Atlantic City with an eye toward entering the market. "An opportunity for our company in Atlantic City could occur," said Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, in a statement. "We want to be in a position to proceed."

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Hilton Hotels Corporation will take over management of the luxury hotel at Taba, the Red Sea resort once disputed by Egypt and Israel, a spokeswoman for the hotel chain said. Nazima Raffa, public relations manager for Hilton in Egypt, said the company would take over the hotel Friday from Sonesta International Hotels.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHY, investors on Wall Street are asking themselves, has the stock of the Hilton Hotels Corporation been rising steadily in the last few days when the casino and lodging company seems to have successfully fought off the unwelcome advances of Stephen A. Wynn and his Golden Nugget? In answer, they point to vague rumors that somebody else may have set his sights on taking over Hilton, or that the company's management might even be planning a deal of its own. Hilton's stock, which has risen 3 3/4 points in the past two sessions, closing at 68 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, seems to be benefiting from a variety of rumors, the loudest of which is that the company might use cash it recently raised to buy back some of its publicly held shares. But that is only part of the speculation. Investment banking sources say there have been more interesting rumors that Hilton is trying to raise additional funds, and this has created suspicions that the company might eventually attempt a leveraged buyout.

headline.main: NEW YORK A PLEASANT SURPRISE FOR 15 FOREIGN CHEFS

docs.lead_paragraph: THE assignment was an enviable one. During a recent five-week period the ''students,'' 15 chefs from the Far East, Europe, the Caribbean and the Middle East, were required to visit as many New York restaurants as possible and report on them. This homework was part of a kitchen-management course at the Career Development Institute run at the Vista International Hotel in Lower Manhattan by Hilton International for its employees. Selection for this training program for professionals is highly competitive and carries considerable prestige in the company. Still, several of the chefs who had never been to New York before confessed initial reluctance at the idea of sampling the restaurants.

headline.main: Net for Hilton Hotels Up 17.5% in 1954; Revenues of $120,609,218 Set a Record

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hilton Hotels Corporation had a consolidated net profit of $4,954,853 last year. That was an increase of 17.5 per cent over the $4,218,450 realized from operations in 1953.

headline.main: HOTELMEN ASK MORE MARSHALL PLAN FUNDS

docs.abstract: T J Pozzy sees record US travel abroad, '50
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- More Marshall Plan aid and a further freeing of exchange for tourism are the two pressing needs of the European hotel industry, it was agreed at the Third Congress of the International Hotels Association meeting here last week. The congress included 750 delegates representing twenty-eight countries.
